items.title: [Whitelisted Caller] Reduce the number of pending messages allowed in an HRMP channel
items.content:
Equivalent of Polkadot referenda https://polkadot.subsquare.io/referenda/1740

By default, when opening an HRMP channel, the number of pending messages that can be queued on the relay chain for the channel is the one defined in the active host configuration (`HostConfiguration::hrmp_channel_max_capacity`).

The current value is 1000 and this referenda proposes to reduce it to 25.

A sending parachain can push at most 1 HRMP message to the relay chain per block while the receiving parachain processes all the pending messages at once. When the limit of pending messages is reached, the sending parachain can't forward any more HRMP message to the relay chain, having to queue them locally. The local queue also has a backpressure mechanism. Even if the receiving parachain has a delay of a couple of blocks in processing the pending messages, 25 pending messages should be enough for everything to work smoothly. 

And if we're in a corner case where the receiving parachain is stalled, it's best to not have a lot of pending HRMP messages on the relay chain, since this will increase the load on the receiving parachain when it recovers.

The new limit will apply only to newly opened channels. This will not impact the channels that are already opened, which will keep the old limit. 

Also this is just the default limit and it will apply to the channels opened via `establish_channel_with_system` for example. If a bigger limit is needed for an HRMP channel, there are extrinsics that can be used for setting a custom limit.

items.title: [Whitelisted Caller] Upgrade Kusama RC and system chains to 1.7.1
items.content:
This is a referendum that obsoletes the existing [#582 ](https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/582). This is due to the urgency to add this [relay chain fix](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/pull/9564) for the bug that has caused the [Kusama stall](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/issues/9546) on top of the 1.7.0 release.

Once enacted, the Kusama Relay Chain and System Chains will be upgraded to the [ Runtimes 1.7.1 release.](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.7.1).

The highlights of the 1.7.0 release are:
- Integrating "[Empowered XCM Origins](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/799)" features to System Chains,
- Adding [Snowbridge V2 ](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/796)pallets, to enable Snowbridge V2 bridging,
- Upgrading to the latest Polkadot-SDK (2507) that comes with many fixes and enhancements.

For the full list of changes, please read the fellowship [1.7.0 release notes](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.7.0) and [1.7.1 release notes](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.7.1)

If approved, it is scheduled to enact at block [29968624](https://kusama.subscan.io/block/29968624), estimated time 2025-09-05 09:59:08 (UTC).

Whitelist: https://kusama.subsquare.io/fellowship/referenda/111

ðŸš¨ Important note for Ecosystem builders: ðŸš¨

In preparation for the upcoming Asset Hub Migration we changed the behavior of transfer_assets and (limited_)reserve_transfer_assets extrinsics to remove DOT/KSM support. You can find more information about what is changing, which SDK versions are affected, along with instructions on how to follow up in this [guide](https://forum.polkadot.network/t/mandatory-action-guide-for-ahm-broken-native-crosschain-transfers/14634).

We recommend that Parachains and dapp builders switch to using alternative extrinsics as instructed in the guide above, otherwise cross-chain transfers may start failing.

items.title: Superseeded by ref #584
items.content:
This was a referendum to authorize the upgrade of Kusama Relay Chain and System Chains to the [Runtimes 1.7.0 release](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.7.0). This ref is superseeded by [Ref #584](https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/584) which upgrades to 1.7.1 instead.

As a consequence I removed the preimage behind this referenda so it will fail either way.

items.title: [Whitelisted Caller] Upgrade remaining system chains to 1.6.x, enable RFC-103 and fix XCM version subscriptions
items.content:
The proposal aims to upgrade system chains to [v1.6.1](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.6.1) along with two calls:
- enabling [RFC-103](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/RFCs/pull/103), which makes Elastic Scaling safer by ensuring each parachain block is locked to a specific relay-chain core, preventing duplication and boosting performance
- [Fixing XCM version subscriptions for some system chains](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/issues/795)

These are being bundled into one proposal to avoid multiple back-to-back whitelisted referenda. Hence, the Fellowship is also voting in parallel to whitelist the proposal hash. Further details can be found in the proposal post. If approved, it is scheduled to enact at block [29613600](https://kusama.subscan.io/block/29613600).

items.title: [Whitelisted Caller] Runtime Upgrade to v1.6.1
items.content:
This referendum is part of the upgrade path to enable Elastic Scaling. It contains the polkadot-sdk `2503-7` update which among other things adds support for slashing/disabling validators that dispute valid candidates and validator re-enabling. This is expected to significantly improve how the system handles dispute spam and allows us to enable RFC103 without causing the finality issues we have seen on our [first attempt](https://forum.polkadot.network/t/2025-05-09-kusama-dispute-storm-postmortem/12947) . 

For the full list of changes, please read the fellowship [1.6.0](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.6.0) and  [1.6.1](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.6.1) release notes.

Enactment is set at blockÂ [29144360](https://kusama.subscan.io/block/29144360), estimated time: 2025-07-09 08:00:28Â (UTC)

Whitelist:Â https://kusama.subsquare.io/fellowship/referenda/108

items.title: Upgrade Coretime system chain to 1.6.0, +40 cores
items.content:
## Description

There are two changes proposed here:

    - A runtime upgrade of Coretime system chain to 1.6.0.
    - Increasing the number of cores from 100 to 140.

The runtime upgrade is meant to fix the current Coretime [situation](https://forum.polkadot.network/t/april-2025-coretime-purchase/12526) on Kusama. It does this by the following:

    1. We configure a minimum price of 1 KSM, to prevent prices to drop to unreasonable low values, which cause the system to take forever to recover in case demand picks up.
    2. Renewals are now no longer completely decoupled from the market, but will be adjusted to cost at least the end price of the current sale. Immediate effect will be that renewals will be adjusted to the minimum price too.

Details are outlined in https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/RFCs/pull/149.

Some fellowship members had a call with all parachain teams describing changes of RFC-149 in detail and from what I know they were on board and want the coretime issue get fixed.

The enactment block was chosen to be https://kusama.subscan.io/block/29059999. Note however, that both changes will take place in the next sale period after the enactment, which is around July 21/22.

## Build

```
opengov-cli build-upgrade --network kusama --only --coretime "1.6.0"
# modify the build call to 0x630004000100b50f04082f0000060202eb4353e21a0600a428020800095b5a86cc8055e729b7b8660f2f551d8bfe6712b24d2e637a0624444addcc8d2e32128c00
opengov-cli submit-referendum \
    --proposal "0x630004000100b50f04082f0000060202eb4353e21a0600a428020800095b5a86cc8055e729b7b8660f2f551d8bfe6712b24d2e637a0624444addcc8d2e32128c00" \
    --network "kusama" --track whitelistedcaller --at 29059999
```

items.content:
The dev team was informed of a security issue affecting Polkadot-sdk. More information will come after the fix. This runtime upgrade aims to fix the issue, changes can be found on the release. Please note the upgrade is submitted on Whitelisted Caller track, meaning the Fellowship is voting on a parallel submission to whitelist this proposal hash.

Please review and vote at your convenience!

Update: as posted by RTTI-5220 below, a post-mortem on the issue and the fix can be found [here](https://forum.polkadot.network/t/2025-05-23-polkadot-sdk-transaction-depth-limit/13248).

items.title: Increase usable cores to 140
items.content:
Recently [Ref#511](https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/511) increased the validator set size to 700 and it was expected to increase the usable cores to 140, this ref does this.



**EDIT:** (extra context)

As I've shared in the comments and other channels, my main motivation for more cores to be available besides the correctness of matching the number of active validators is to allow teams missing a core to have a fair chance to purchase one on the next sale period.

Our parachain Kreivo failed to renew and is now dependent on manually producing blocks on-demand which greatly hurts usability for our users. Instead of requesting a direct core assignment like it was \[done in Polkadot]\(https://polkadot.subsquare.io/referenda/1536), I believe this approach is simpler and fairer as it gives anyone an equal chance to get their core.

items.title: [Whitelisted Caller] Update schedulerParams.lookahead configuration parameter to 3
items.content:
This referenda increases `schedulerParams.lookahead` value to 3.

## Why this change is needed?
`scheduler.lookahead` determines the size of the claim queue and at the moment is set to `2`. The claim queue shows which parachains are about to be scheduled on a specific core. A value of two shows what will be scheduled for a window of **two blocks**.

`asyncBackingParams.allowedAncestryLen` is an async backing parameter which determines the oldest relay parent a candidate can be built on. 2 here means that a candidate can be built on the latest know relay parent or the **two** relay parents before it. In total this gives a window of **three** blocks.

So we have got a discrepancy. Async backing will accept candidates based on three different blocks while the claim queue shows information only about two. Bumping `schedulerParams.lookahead` to 3 will correctly align these values.

items.title: Fix TotalIssuance
items.content:
# Fixing The Total Issuance

TLDR: A historic bug caused the Total Issuance tracking to deviate from the actual Issuance. I propose a [whitelisted call](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Frpc.ibp.network%2Fkusama#/extrinsics/decode/0x0409010bc197e4aa3b33) to re-align them. The underlying issue has already been resolved.

There was an [issue discovered](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/issues/147) on Kusama that the sum of all accounts' balances does not match the Total Issuance stored in `pallet-balances`. This is a serious issue, since third parties rely on its accuracy for tracking the total amount of existing tokens.
The underlying problem was fixed by [#1222](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/pull/1222) and [#3707](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/pull/3707). The TI has not drifted further, but the same problem is present on Polkadot.

## The Difference

First, it is necessary to measure the exact drift between the expected and the actual Total Issuance. This can be done by querying a node at a fixed block height. Two things have to be queried: all account entries and the TI variable from the balances pallet.  
Conveniently, [this script](https://github.com/ggwpez/substrate-scripts/blob/master/check-ti-complete.py) does both. The exact numbers were determined by running these commands against a Kusama archive RPC:

```bash
python3 check-ti-complete.py --url <RPC> block --trace 24407008
python3 check-ti-complete.py --url <RPC> block --trace 23780225
```

:::spoiler
```bash
git clone https://github.com/ggwpez/substrate-scripts
# Setup local Python env
python3 -m venv venv
venv/bin/pip install substrate-interface
venv/bin/python3 check-ti-complete.py --url wss://rpc.ibp.network/kusama block 23780225 --trace
```
:::

Console output from both commands:

```pre
[24407008] The TotalIssuance is larger than the sum of all accounts TI. TI: 15,311,516.288236268 KSM, Sum: 15,311,459.956873074 KSM
[24407008] TI must be decreased by 15311516288236268206 - 15311459956873073389 = 56331363194817 (56.331363194817 KSM)

[23780225] The TotalIssuance is larger than the sum of all accounts TI. TI: 15,131,305.14570446 KSM, Sum: 15,131,248.814341264 KSM
[23780225] TI must be decreased by 15131305145704458736 - 15131248814341263919 = 56331363194817 (56.331363194817 KSM)
```

The JSON output in the file `blocks-ti.json` tells us the resulting numbers:

```json
{"block": 24407008, "sum": 15311459956873073389, "ti": 15311516288236268206, "runtime": "Parity Polkadot", "diff": 56331363194817}
{"block": 23780225, "sum": 15131248814341263919, "ti": 15131305145704458736, "runtime": "Parity Polkadot", "diff": 56331363194817}
```

This means that the difference is now stable since the last runtime upgrade that was 626,783 blocks ago.  
The `diff` field shows shows the exact difference in planks: `56331363194817`. The TI is larger than the sum; we therefore need to *decrease* the TI by that amount.

## Referendum

The call to fix this is [pallet-balances::force_adjust_total_issuance](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/pull/3001):

```rust
fn force_adjust_total_issuance(
	direction: AdjustmentDirection,
	#[pallet::compact] delta: T::Balance,
)
```

`AdjustmentDirection` can be either `Increase` or `Decrease`. This can be used to correct the TI to be re-aligned with the actual sum of all accounts' balances.

The final call is [0x0409010bc197e4aa3b33](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Frpc.ibp.network%2Fkusama#/extrinsics/decode/0x0409010bc197e4aa3b33):

![Screenshot 2024-08-09 at 17.07.56](https://hackmd.io/_uploads/S1dCg3X5R.png)

A similar post and referendum for Polkadot will follow once it was executed correctly on Kusama.

items.title: Unlock para 2281 (Kreivo)
items.content:
## The Incident

On Saturday, June 29, Kreivo stopped producing blocks after a runtime upgrade to version [0.13.0](https://github.com/virto-network/virto-node/compare/0.12.1...0.13.0). This upgrade aimed to introduce pallet contracts, enable bridged DOT reception from Kusama AssetHub, and update our PolkadotSDK dependency from version 1.5 to 1.12. The main goal was to prepare Kreivo for async backing, which would reduce block times from 12 to 6 seconds.

## The Issue

Despite thorough testing before the upgrade, the problem only appeared hours after enactment(at the end of the era). The current rapid development of the PolkadotSDK makes it challenging for small teams like ours to constantly update and migrate code. Our main issue stemmed from the significant version jump (1.5 to 1.12), likely missing crucial intermediate migrations.

## Impact

While most of our users (DAOs) are aware of Kreivo's beta testing stage and aren't critically affected, two key exceptions are:

1. Virto team: Our salaries are paid through the DAO's governance, which is currently inaccessible.
2. KSM Community: This decentralized voice in Kusama can't vote on OpenGov proposals.

## Proposed Solution

While this proposal is being voted on, we'll prepare an updated WASM of the runtime that fixes the issue. Unlocking Kreivo means the "manager account" will be able to do a `schedule_code_upgrade` to manually set the updated parachain's code in the relay chain to match the code manually set by collators with the `codeSubstitute` feature of the chainspec.

## Request

We ask Kusama governance and the Fellowship to approve unlocking the Kreivo parachain so we can restore functionality. After resolution, we'll conduct a public postmortem and implement additional safeguards for the future.

We are glad this kind of issue occurred this early in the lifetime of the chain when impact is manageable and are now more convinced builders need simpler ways to manage this kind of outages, ironically I believe a "governance parachain" like Kreivo where parachains can host their governance can be a great solution to this issue as people can vote to unlock a parachain even if it has halted.

items.title: Kusama Runtime Upgrade to 1.2.2
items.content:
This proposal aims to upgrade Kusama to the lastest release ([1.2.2](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.2.2)): aiming to fix some issues encountered with core sales and bridges. 

When Kusama upgraded to the [1.2.0Â runtime](https://kusama.polkassembly.io/referenda/373) it migrated itself to Coretime. This migration is done by iterating the current state of parachains and sending this information to the Coretime chain using multiple Xcm messages. One of these Xcm messages is setting up the leases to match the leases of the old auction model (this should ensure that parachains that won leases using the old auction model still get Coretime until the end of their lease). However, this Xcm message failed to execute because of aÂ WeightÂ mismatch (the thirdÂ `message.Processed`Â eventÂ [here](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Fkusama-coretime-rpc.polkadot.io#/explorer/query/0x006a92a7615a939866e74f90889b9b12d1268edc67a473359a66e50c2ba012c4%5D(https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Fkusama-coretime-rpc.polkadot.io%23/explorer/query/0x006a92a7615a939866e74f90889b9b12d1268edc67a473359a66e50c2ba012c4))Â showing successÂ false). Basically this means that the message announced would use less weight than what it would actually use and this made the Xcm message fail. This is a security measurement to ensure that Xcm messages cannot stall a chain.

For this reason, a runtime upgrade is proposed that reruns the Xcm message, but also includes aÂ [fix](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/pull/4089)Â that ensures that every parachain that had a lease before core sales start can renew their core. The side effect of this runtime upgrade is that the sales state is reset, meaning that the sales start 7 days after this runtime upgrade is applied.

**Changes on Kusama BridgeHub 1.2.2 upgrade**

The Polkadot-GRANDPA-light-client running on Kusama BH doesnâ€™t correctly handle a corner case involving validator set changes following validator slashing. As a result of the bug, the GRANDPA light-client can fail to recognise the other side's validator set change and thus start refusing to accept subsequent validator set changes as well. More details can be found onÂ [this forum post](https://forum.polkadot.network/t/polkadot-kusama-bridge/2971/45).

We have encountered this bug on the Polkadot BH, resulting in Kusama->Polkadot traffic being stuck. This upgrade fixes the bug for Kusama BH so that it is protected from encountering the same issue.

Please note this proposal is submitted on Whitelisted Caller track - a parallel submission is up for vote on Fellowship to whitelist this proposal.

items.title: Enable Coretime
items.content: This is a referendum to send a set of calls to the Coretime chain that will configure the Broker pallet and start Coretime sales.

items.title: Enable async backing on kusama
items.content:
This referendum is meant for enabling async-backing on kusama, more information about what is async backing and what this parameter changes will do can be found here [async backing](https://wiki.polkadot.network/docs/learn-async-backing)

Currently on kusama, all async backing logic has been enabled since [v1.1.0](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.1.0) runtime was enacted, but it is running in sync mode, parachains can produce block only at 12s rate.

After this referendum parachains can decide to produce blocks at 6s rate, by following this guide https://wiki.polkadot.network/docs/maintain-guides-async-backing, but that is not mandatory, they will still run at 12s rate without any changes needed on their side.

## Testing done

Async backing has been running on Rococo since December 2023 and on Westend since February 2023 with all system parachains migrated to produce blocks at 6s rate.

Our final checklist enablement can be found here: https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/issues/3226

## Dependencies

Some critical fixes for async backing are in the upcoming `v1.2` runtime release, so this referendum is configured to be enacted **AFTER** v1.2 https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/373 release has been enacted.

Whitelisted by: https://kusama.subsquare.io/fellowship/referenda/70
## Known issues

No critical issues are known at this moment, however since the async backing subsystems in sync mode has been enabled a few issues that have arosed, this referendum **won't change** anything regarding that.

- There are still around 3-5% validators in the active set that are not upgrade, so when it is their turn to 
  back they won't back anything, and if 2 out of 3 nodes are in the same backing group the group won't be 
  able to back the candidates it is assigned to. **Action** Un-upgraded validators please upgrade to 
  something higher than 1.8 node version.
- New validators entering the active set will get 0 backing point the first session they enter, **Action** No action needed it has [been fixed with](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/pull/3722) and will be included in 1.2 runtime release.
- Validators were accidentally changing they network-key(PeerId) at restart/upgradge which made them to not be properly discovered by the network for 36h and get 0 backing rewards. **Action** Double-check your validators doesn't do that, the network key is persistent next to the `db` so make sure it gets persisted across restarts, [more details](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/pull/3722)

items.content:
This upgrades the Kusama system to the [Fellowship v1.2.0 release](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.2.0). Most notably, this release includes the migration to Coretime.

Enactment is set for 18 April.

items.title: Register Coretime Parachain
items.content:
This is a call to register the Coretime parachain. Once registered, the rest of the Kusama system can upgrade to v1.2.0, migrating all leases to Coretime. A separate referendum will start the sale of Coretime via the Coretime chain.

This is based off of the Coretime runtime in the [Fellowship v1.2.0 release](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.2.0).

items.title: Bump parachain validation timeouts
items.content:
### Description

This proposal aims to increase the backing timeout on validators from 2s to 2.5s and approval-voting timeout from 12s to 15s respectively.

The rationale for the change can be found in https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/issues/3565. In short, this will help ensuring smoother experience for async backing parachains wishing to utilize the full 2s of execution per block.

### Checking

The details of the call can be found here: https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Frpc-kusama.luckyfriday.io#/extrinsics/decode/0x332e0c01002000000600c4090000000000000601983a000000000000.

In addition to setting the timeouts, the `MaxMemoryPage` param is being set to the value it was set before, since the call overrides every param of `ExecutorParams`.

### Testing

This call has been tested locally with zombienet as well as on Rococo.

items.title: Migrate 25k KSM to Asset Hub Treasury
items.content:
This referendum moves 25k KSM (roughly 10%) of the Kusama Treasury from its account on the Relay Chain to its account on Asset Hub. It also sets the asset rate of KSM to 1 (since the conversion of KSM to KSM is unitary). Having an asset rate value is required to spend from the Treasury on Asset Hub.

This requires root privilege, but once the funds are on Asset Hub, it will allow normal operation with the Treasurer and XSpender tracks.

Having the funds on Asset Hub will enable new Treasury features like staged spends (detailed by [@muharem](/user/muharem) [on the forum](https://forum.polkadot.network/t/multi-asset-treasury-and-milestone-based-spends/6780)). When this works successfully, I will propose the same thing on Polkadot, where we can take advantage of more features like USDC/T spends and funding sub-treasuries.

items.title: [Please reject] Enable async backing on kusama
items.content:
## Please reject

Preimage is wrong will let this one timeout and resubmit a correct one after `v1.2` runtime release gets posted.

This referendum is meant for enabling async-backing on kusama, more information about what is async backing and what this parameter changes will do can be found here [async backing](https://wiki.polkadot.network/docs/learn-async-backing)

items.title: Setting onDemandBaseFee to 0.005 KSM
items.content:
This proposal sets the minimum fee for an order for a single block via the on-demand system to be 0.005 KSM. The reason for the change is to set a starting point that is high enough to deter spam but low enough that experimentation would not be cost-prohibitive.

If this minimum is found out to be too high after the on-demand system goes live, another proposal to lower the base fee should be proposed.

Note that the proposal has been submitted on the Whitelisted Caller track, meaning the Fellowship will be also voting shortly to whitelist the submission hash.

items.title: Fund system chains sovereign accounts on Kusama BridgeHub for Polkadot<>Kusama bridge
items.content: The P<>K bridge charges user fees on originating Asset Hub, but it pays relayer rewards from AssetHubs' sovereign accounts on sibling BridgeHub parachains. These relayer rewards are a large part of the bridge's "operating costs". For initial deployment, AssetHub's sovereign accounts on BridgeHubs should be pre-funded by treasury. An initial 10100 DOT and 2030 KSM is proposed to be split among the relevant system chain sovereign accounts to provide initial bootstrap runway to the bridge. This will only be an initial seed. As the bridge operates, it should cover operation costs (relayer fees) from the user fees paid on Asset Hub, and any unspent user fees ("bridge profits") are going to the treasury anyway, so in the longer term these funds are practically paid back (plus profits). Exact system chain addresses being funded and amounts for each can be found here: https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/issues/238

items.title: Kusama Runtime Upgrade v1.1.3
items.content:
This is a referendum to upgrade the system to the [v1.1.3 Fellowship release](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.1.3).

This release bumps the Staking pallet version. This patch prevents staking controllers from becoming stashes, which may lead to ledger inconsistencies. Patch and context: [paritytech/polkadot-sdk#3639](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/pull/3639).

history.content:
The purpose of this call is to initialize the Kusama side of the Polkadot<>Kusama bridge.

It does the following:

Calls `forceXcmVersion` on following system parachains to set XCMv3 between:

    Kusama AH <-> Kusama BH
    Kusama BH -> Polkadot BH
    Kusama AH -> Polkadot AH

It then calls `bridgePolkadotGrandpa::initialize()` with the initial configuration for the Polkadot on-chain light-cLient running on Kusama Bridge Hub.

(resubmission of referenda #354 with correct enactment block)

items.title: Setting setOnDemandQueueMaxSize to 500
items.content:
The shift from 10,000 to 500 is prompted by a discovery on Rococo. When a parachain placed a batch call for approximately 5,000 orders in a single block, coupled with Rococo's abundance of on-demand cores at the time, block import times slowed significantly, as evident in [the reported issue](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/issues/3051). To address this temporarily, we're restricting the total number of orders by adjusting the configuration through `configuration.setOnDemandMaxQueueSize` to a smaller value, and for the initial launch, 500 is a safe limit. Once a more permanent solution is in place, the maximum orders can be revisited.

Note that the OnDemandQueue stores orders made on the relay chain which have yet to be assigned a core. The maximum size represented by `onDemandMaxQueueSize` is the absolute maximum that this storage entry can be. It is further bounded via an optimal price controller, which is currently set to try and maintain 0-25% of the max capacity without increasing the price of an order.

items.title: Clean up undecodable Locks and SessionKeys
items.content:
This referendum cleans up all undecodable keys from storage.

The first 19 keys removed are undecodable Locks, which were not migrated correctly during a runtime upgrade in 2019. See [this issue](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/issues/104) and [this PR](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/pull/122) for more info.

The remaining 381 keys removed are undecodable, inactive SessionKeys also likely created due to a bad runtime upgrade. See [this comment](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/issues/140#issuecomment-1898081577), [this issue](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot-sdk/issues/1149), and [this other issue](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/issues/151) for more info.

This call was programatically created and verified for safety checking that

1.  There are no longer any undecodable keys on Kusama
2.  Only Locks from the faulty 2019 runtime upgrade are removed
3.  No session keys removed are from the active validator set

using the code at [this commit](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/compare/mainâ€¦liamaharon:runtimes:liam-kusama-undecodable-keys-check-safe-removal).

Whitelisted by Fellowship in [this referenda](https://kusama.subsquare.io/fellowship/referenda/57).

---

The identity for [this account](https://www.subscan.io/account/DDdfRGvKc9i2BTnqe5T2yBYuY88DxVmCjs66pLiy77TskWo) is verified on Polkadot - `liamaharon` Fellowship rank I.

items.title: Upgrade Kusama Asset Hub to Patch Release v1.1.1
items.content: This is an upgrade of Asset Hub to the [v1.1.1 release](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.1.1), which includes the correction for lowering the existential deposit.

items.title: Update Sufficient Asset Minimum Balances
items.content:
This referendum is related to the reduction of existential deposit on Kusama's Asset Hub.

When you pay fees in `sufficient` assets, the system still calculates the base transaction fee in KSM. It converts it to the asset fee amount using the ratio of minimum balances. So:

```
fee_in_ksm * asset_min_balance / ksm_existential_deposit
```

So, if you reduce the KSM ED by a factor of 10, you also increase fees in sufficient assets by a factor of 10.

This proposal reduces the minimum balance requirement for all sufficient assets (USDT, RMRK, and DOT) by a factor of 10, preserving the ratio. There is also a fourth call to update the metadata for bridged DOT, since that [failed when creating the asset](<258>) due to the `SafeCallFilter`.

The enactment block (21,570,500) is set just before the Asset Hub would upgrade to the lower ED.

history.content:
This referendum is related to the reduction of existential deposit on Kusama's Asset Hub.

When you pay fees in `sufficient` assets, the system still calculates the base transaction fee in KSM. It converts it to the asset fee amount using the ratio of minimum balances. So:

```
fee_in_ksm * asset_min_balance / ksm_existential_deposit
```

So, if you reduce the KSM ED by a factor of 10, you also increase fees in sufficient assets by a factor of 10.

This proposal updates the minimum balance requirement for all sufficient assets (USDT, RMRK, and DOT) by a factor of 10, preserving the ratio. There is also a fourth call to update the metadata for bridged DOT, since that [failed when creating the asset](https://kusama.polkassembly.io/referenda/258) due to the `SafeCallFilter`.

The enactment block (21,570,500) is set just before the Asset Hub would upgrade to the lower ED.

items.title: Runtime Upgrade v1,001,000
items.content:
This is a proposal to upgrade the Kusama system to v1.1.0. See the [Fellowship release notes](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.1.0) for more info.

Enactment is set for 24 Jan.

items.title: Setting the relay chain's safeXcmVersion to v3
items.content:
In light of the recent upgrade of the Kusama relay chain, an XCM issue has surfaced. This problem arises because the Kusama relay chain appends a `SetTopic` instruction to every XCM program. However, XCM version 2, which is currently the default for many destinations, does not support this instruction.  Consequently, when the Kusama relay chain sends an XCM message to a destination, it believes is using v2 (even if that destination has actually upgraded to v3), the SetTopic instruction triggers an error, leading to failed transactions.

The mismatch in XCM versions can lead to issues between the relay chain and parachains. To resolve this, we propose setting the relay chain's `safeXcmVersion` to v3. This adjustment ensures that the relay chain will send XCMs in the v3 format by default. Moreover, defaulting to v3 on the relay chain isn't just a temporary fix. It's a strategic move for the long term.

items.title: Upgrade Kusama v1,000,000
items.content:
This referendum updates the Kusama Relay Chain and its Asset Hub and Bridge Hub to v1,000,000, with runtimes pulled from the [Fellowship v1.0.0 release](https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/runtimes/releases/tag/v1.0.0). See the release notes for information specific to this release.

Requires whitelist by https://kusama.subsquare.io/fellowship/referenda/51

items.title: Set backing group size to 3
items.content: The backing group size on Kusama (and Polkadot) has been set to 5 (configuration->activeConfig->maxValidatorsPerCore). This proposal is aiming at reducing the group size to 3. Currently, when a parachain produces a block, it requires 2 out of 5 backing validators to verify and sign it in order to back it and move forward. With 2-of-3, we'd guarantee that backing quorum is a group supermajority, so there're not two competing 2/5 backed candidates. And one extra validator is allowed to be slow. Smaller backing groups should also contribute to distributing the load of approval-checking more evenly. There's a small risk, however, that with slow/unresponsive validators, parachain slots might be skipped more often with 2/3 instead of 2/5. This should not be an issue in practice since validator groups rotate every minute.

items.title: Fixing Inclusion Issues On Parachains Side
items.content:
This morning CEST Kusama parachains stopped including blocks. The cause was a dispute in a finalized block that stopped the inclusion of new blocks from parachains.

After the chain issued a revert, it "freezes" the current chain to not include any new parachain candidates. As the block was already finalized, we could not revert to and continued producing on this chain. So, the chain currently is rejecting any new parachain candidates.Â force\_unfreezeÂ reverts the freeze. This proposal aims to fix this, for chains to continue with block inclusion.

Info on all submissions below:

-   Preimage for the Fellowship referendum: [https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Fkusama-rpc.polkadot.io#/extrinsics/decode/0x2000882c0090e492d7fc2315e0ad47eb060fe96b2c428260eb15ede5519d1476a962d0a0fc](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Fkusama-rpc.polkadot.io#/extrinsics/decode/0x2000882c0090e492d7fc2315e0ad47eb060fe96b2c428260eb15ede5519d1476a962d0a0fc)

items.title: Register DOT on Asset Hub
items.content:
Enacting this proposal will register the asset `{ parents: 2, interior: GlobalConsensus(Polkadot) }` on the Kusama Asset Hub. It also adds metadata (name: "Polkadot", symbol: "DOT"). DOT will be a sufficient asset with a minimum balance of 0.01 DOT.

The "owner" of the asset is the account ID conversion of the path (expressed as a Multilocation) to the Polkadot Relay Chain, i.e. the governance location of Polkadot.

This registration by governance is part of the initialization of a Polkadot <> Kusama bridge. Future assets that are sent over the bridge will _not_ need governance motions from the system Root origin. There will be a similar referendum to register KSM on Polkadot.

items.title: Increase MaxMemoryPages to 512MB
items.content:
PVF execution currently has a memory limit of 128MB, which is the same as Cumulus uses for its block import pipeline. While collators execute state transitions by reading parachain data from disk locally, parachain validators must load state proofs into memory. Therefore, they should have a higher memory limit than collators. Otherwise a parachain block that made full use of memory when executed by the collator could fail to be executed by validators. To fix this, we propose increasing the memory limit for PVF execution to 512MB.


```
set_config_with_executor_params {}: set_executor_params(RawOrigin::Root, 
ExecutorParams::from(&[ExecutorParam::MaxMemoryPages(8192)][..]))
```

- hash: `0x1c356149b664ec3f7d89eeb56a3469bd5f468ae7fafa2b13f2423618db6c922e`

items.title: Update Parachain Validation No Show Slots
items.content:
At the request of Parity's Parachains Core team, this updates the `no_show_slots` configuration from `2` to `3`.

This increase provides more time for validators to fetch a PoV and run the parachain validation function in adverse network conditions. Increasing the no show time limit reduces the number of missed approvals and will reduce the load on the network.

Requires whitelist by https://kusama.subsquare.io/fellowship/referendum/44

items.title: Open HRMP Channel Between Asset Hub and Bridge Hub
items.content: This referendum opens an HRMP channel between the system chains Asset Hub and Bridge Hub. This channel will support representing bridged assets on Asset Hub. Relies on Fellowship passing https://kusama.polkassembly.io/member-referenda/42

items.title: Upgrade Kusama to v9430
items.content:
This referendum upgrades the Kusama network (Relay Chain, Asset Hub, and Bridge Hub) to v9430. See the release notes for the [Relay Chain](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/releases/tag/v0.9.43) and [parachains](https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/releases/tag/parachains-v9430) for more details.

Enactment is set for Monday 03 July, roughly mid-morning European time.

items.title: Increase Parachain Validators to 300
items.content: Following good network stability with 250 parachain validators (as set in [Referendum 188](https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/referendum/188)), this further increases the number of validators participating in parachain validation from 250 to 300.

items.title: Update `relayVrfModuloSamples` in Parachain Config
items.content:
This is a follow up to https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/referendum/188. It adjusts the `relayVrfModuloSamples` to 6 in the parachain validation configuration. The reason it can be lowered so much is because the disputes protocol is now live.

Requires whitelisting in https://kusama.subsquare.io/fellowship/referendum/39

items.title: Runtime Upgrade v9420 on Kusama and v9420 on System Parachains
items.content:
This proposal aims upgrade Kusama relay chain to runtime [v9420](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/releases/tag/v0.9.42) and Kusama System Parachains (Statemint/Collectives) to runtime [v9420](https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/releases/tag/parachains-v9420): the specific details on this upgrade please check the release notes. This release contains the changes fromÂ v0.9.41Â toÂ v0.9.42. Please note there are 4 runtime migrations for relay chain on this release (details below), and in addition to the migrations mentioned above, all the migrations included in runtimes since v9380 have been included in this release, allowing to jump over a few runtimes. 

- Call Hash: `0xf3872cfebdcb48512eeaf8914e442398b85ace552d0c172623f2e7341c80638d`

- Preimage is submitted: Submission should have the hash: `0x2142648ddbdc47fe9ff8d402f47004e442851810de188a25733bcfb7f0e0d3fb`

- [P]Â â³Â pending non-critical auditÂ [#6934](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/pull/6934)Â Low - Enable changing executor params through governance

- [P]Â âœ…Â auditedÂ [#6843](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/pull/6843)Â Low - Xcm: properly set the pricing for the dmp router

- [S]Â [#13779](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/13779)Â Low - Add freeze/thaw events and tests

- [P]Â [#6662](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/pull/6662)Â Low - Xcm: remote account converter

- [S]Â âœ…Â trivialÂ [#13827](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/13827)Â Low - Pallet-democracy: do not request the proposal when scheduling

- [S]Â âœ…Â auditedÂ [#13936](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/13936)Â â—ï¸Â Medium - Removes reportsbykindindex

- [P]Â [#7114](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/pull/7114)Â â—ï¸Â Medium - Offences migration v1: removesÂ reportsbykindindex

- [S]Â âœ…Â trivialÂ [#13988](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/13988)Â â—ï¸Â Medium - Pallet collective: fix genesis member sort order

- [P]Â â³Â pending non-critical auditÂ [#7098](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/pull/7098)Â Low - Xcm: implement a blocking barrier

- [S]Â â³Â pending non-critical auditÂ [#13932](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/13932)Â Low - Frame: inherited call weight syntax

- [P]Â âœ…Â trivial [#7150](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/pull/7150) Low - Update weights

**System parachains Runtime**

This Kusama system parachains upgrade includes changes since v9382. Most notably, this includes the new NFT 2.0 pallet (`pallet-nft`) on Statemine. This includes a number of new functionalities like smart attributes. More features can be found in the primary [tracking issue](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/issues/11783). As the audit has been completed, this will be coming soon to Statemint.

This release also includes a [new instance of the Assets pallet](https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/pull/2133), called `ForeignAssets`. Foreign Assets uses a `MultiLocation` as an asset class identifier and allows other parachains (and eventually bridges) to represent their native assets directly on Statemine. For example, the asset ID of the native asset of Parachain 9000 would be `{ parents: 1, interior: X1(Parachain(9000)) }`. The original instance of the Assets pallet remains, and is often referred to as the â€œTrust Backedâ€ Assets pallet, denoting the fact that they are administered by an account that one trusts to have some off-chain, corresponding asset.

Finally, there is a new runtime API to [query account balances](https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/pull/2455), which will return all the fungible assets (under the Balances pallet and both instances of the Assets pallet) that an account owns in a single RPC call. This should be particularly useful for front end developers.

**Please note this proposal is submitted on Whitelisted Caller track: meaning parallel to this public proposal, the whitelist of the proposal hash for this submission is also up for vote by the Fellowship (link [here](https://kusama.subsquare.io/fellowship/referendum/38)).**

If the proposal is approved, enactment will happen in block #18,062,739. 

Make sure to vote at your convenience!

items.title: Opening up HRMP Channel between GM & MangataX Parachains
items.content:
Hello,

I've created the following referendum to open up HRMP channels between the GM parachain which is supposed to be a community project created for fun to send and receive GMs and GNs
and MangataX which is a DEX so that community members have the freedom to add liquidity for the FREN coin which is currently not listed anywhere. 
This will allow anyone who wants to obtain FREN to do so anytime they chose.

The following calls will be made:

- A **forcetransfer** of 10 KSM from the **Treasury** to **Statemine** account (It automatically swaps the MangataX address to the Statemine address on Kusama)
- A **forceopenhrmpchannel** from **MangataX** (2,110) to **GM** [2,123].
- A **forceopenhrmpchannel** from **GM** [2,123] to **MangataX** (2,110).

This is also a fun experiment because I've never actually created this kind of request before so I thought I'd give it a try.

Now the challenge is who will be happy to block 333.33 KSM as a decision deposit for this for the next 14 days   ;-) 

Regards,

Claudio

items.title: Kusama Runtime Upgrade 938*
items.content:
This is a proposal to upgrade Kusama to the Relay Chain 9381 and System Parachains 9382 releases. As with the previous (cancelled) referenda, this includes the upgrade to XCM v3. This proposal is a bit dense, so will break it down. It's a `force_batch`, meaning that even if one of the calls fails, it will still execute the later ones.

The first two calls are `xcm.send` extrinsics that send `authorize_upgrade` messages to Statemine and the BridgeHub.

The next two schedule calls on the Relay Chain to set the XCM version it uses to communicate with Statemine and the BridgeHub to `3`. They are scheduled for 600 blocks (1 hour) later because that is the upgrade delay imposed on parachains. So it should update to 3 at about the same time that the parachains upgrade. We've done a lot of testing on local networks, but please be careful around this time with calls that handle funds (teleport, reserve asset transfers).

The last call is the Relay Chain runtime upgrade, wrapped in its `with_weight` dress.

Finally, I configured this to enact, if passed, at block 17,335,450. If I calculated right, this should be about 11:00 UTC on Tuesday 04 April. This should be a _convenient enough_ time for most time zones.

Releases where I took the runtime Wasm files:

- [Relay Chain](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/releases/tag/v0.9.38-rc12)
- [Parachains](https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/releases/tag/parachains-v9382)

items.title: A New Batch Of HRMP Channels: Amplitude, MangataX, Imbue, Tinkernet, GM Parachain
Remove Old Runtime Upgrade Preimage
items.content:
Due to a bug related to unrequesting preimages, an old (and quite large) preimage is stuck in a `Requested` state. This referendum removes the request so that it can be removed from the chain.

The interpretation of the preimage has also changed since a runtime upgrade changed pallet indices, meaning an original `set_code` preimage has become `kill_storage`.

items.title: System Parachains 9381 Upgrade
items.content:
This proposal updates system parachains to v9381. The main change from v9370 is the introduction of XCM v3. Note that this is "v9381" instead of "v9380" due to late changes in the release process after the Westend parachains had already been upgraded to v9380.

This proposal also tells the Relay Chain to communicate with system parachains using XCM v3 in the future. It is scheduled for 600 blocks after the upgrade authorization to coincide with the actual upgrades.

Release notes are in the [Cumulus repo](https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/releases/tag/parachains-v9380).

items.title: Lease swap for Karura and Mangata
items.content:
Acala Foundation have registered para id 2233 and won a parachain slot auction by bidding with the intention to use the new lease to renew Karura para lease.

However, due to incorrect understanding of the lease swap process, a bad wasm was submitted for para 2233 as it is never intended to run this parachain. However, despite that the auction was won by direct bidding, the parachain is nevertheless locked and therefore para manager is not able to call swap on the parachain. As a result, para 2233 cannot be used.

Mangata team also having a [similar situation](https://kusama.polkassembly.io/referendum/263) that the para wasm for their new para id is not valid and unable to perform lease swap as well.

This proposal aims to perform lease swap between 2000 (Karura) and 2233 (parachain bid by Acala Foundation), and another lease swap between 2110 (Mangata operational parachain) and 2256 (Mangata crowdloan parachain).

In order to prevent similar situation to happen in future, I created [this issue](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/issues/6685) and will try to design a better lease renew process for parachains.

items.title: Kusama Auctions: Third timeâ€™s a charm - STEP 1
items.content:
Kusama auctions are scheduled using theÂ Scheduler Pallet, and the recurring functionality that this brings. The recurrence of this pallet offers two options: every how many blocks this recurrent should be executed, and how many times. Unfortunately,Â [Ref 72](https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/referendum/72)Â andÂ [Ref 81](https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/referendum/81)Â have been misconfigured and the two parameters on the scheduler pallet have been passed in the wrong way: For example, the first scheduler call will not create 2 auctions every 100_800 blocks, but rather 100_800 auctions every two blocks.

**Solution:** both Ref 72 and Ref 81 will have to be cancelled and re-submitted on-chain.

For this, we will work on 3 proposals:

1. Whitelisted caller track proposal cancelling scheduled auctions + ref81;
2. Auction admin track proposal for the first auction on Ref81: this will give us one more week to vote on the third proposal;
3. Root track proposal for all auctions in ref72 + the last auction batch of ref81. 

The first proposal is now submitted and is THIS ONE - this proposal aims to cancel all scheduled auctions that are incorrect on scheduler:

![](https://i.ibb.co/dj91XbC/Screenshot-2023-01-31-at-18-21-45.png)

And [referendum 81](https://kusama.polkassembly.io/referenda/81): up for vote on Root track now. The reason why we are cancelling this proposal is due to the fact the same mistake was made on submission. 

Please note a Fellowship proposal is also needed, up for vote now by its members, to whitelist this proposal hash to make sure the proposal executes successfully. 

Proposal preimage: [HERE](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Fkusama-rpc.polkadot.io#). This has been submitted. 

Please make sure to vote at your convenience!

items.title: Setting pvfCheckingEnabled In The Configuration To TRUE
items.content:
This proposal aims to enable pre-checking for runtime upgrade on parachains: With pre-checking enabled a parachain is only allowed to upgrade their runtime **after validators have tried compiling it and they agree it is good**, as opposed to just accepting it blindly and then fail when the parachain tries to produce blocks with the new runtime. This is just generally a good idea, exists for a while already and has been successfully tested on Versi, Rococo and Westend. It is also required for rolling out slashing as it helps reducing the risk of unjustified slashes.

Parachains need to support the `go_ahead_signal,` but that should be a non issue as this has been introduced over a year ago.

 - Call to be enacted: [HERE](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Frpc.dotters.network%2Fkusama#/extrinsics/decode/0x332901).

- Call wrapped for whitelisted caller track: [HERE](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Fkusama-rpc.polkadot.io#/extrinsics/decode/0x15002b0d028d07075077a0c606e24818b348c5665ae6ffc40b8c50f367fbbf23332d5ade8905000000010a000000).

- Fellowship proposal to be approved by the collective can be found [HERE](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Fkusama-rpc.polkadot.io#/extrinsics/decode/0x2000882c006e1dd036deb360f70a48f98b22e0da5001dbcdc6bb74bab8ca0f17a1fd5fa9b9). The Fellowship proposal is [no. 20](https://kusama.subsquare.io/fellowship/referendum/20). 

Preimages are submitted. Make sure to review and vote at your convenience!

items.title: Register Bridge Hub Parachain
items.content:
This is a proposal to add a Bridge Hub (BH) parachain to Kusama. All technical details can be found in the [Bridge Hub Genesis release](https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/releases/tag/parachains-bridge-hub-kusama-v9360). The runtime is taken from the v9360 parachains release.

The BH will be the gateway between Kusama and other networks, like Polkadot and Ethereum. For now, the BH only contains some basic logic, and none of the bridge-specific pallets. Those will get added in future runtime upgrades; the goal of this proposal is to get approval from Kusama stakeholders and a "shell" operational such that bridge teams can focus on releasing their bridge logic, not launching a parachain.

The BH will primarily act as a message routing system within the network and between others. For example, parachains can configure their XCMP routing to interpret `parents: 2` (indicating, "go to another consensus system") as something to send to the BH to handle. Likewise, the BH can handle incoming messages and route them to the correct parachain within Kusama.

Once operational, a Polkadot<>Kusama bridge will allow more interaction between the networks. For example, the Technical Fellowship can move onto the Polkadot Collectives parachain and serve both networks; or the Kusama network (as a unit body) could join the Polkadot Alliance.

items.title: Encointer runtime upgrade v12 2nd try
items.content:
This is a resubmission of our runtime upgrade which has been whitelisted by fellowship already.
The resubmission is necessary because of several reasons:
1. [referendum 9](https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/referendum/9) would have enacted after 15M blocks instead of instantly
2. our joint [referendum 17](https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/referendum/17) with Statemine has been executed, but during that time, Encointer was no parachain because of:
3. [referendum 243](https://kusama.polkassembly.io/referendum/243) passed, but failed to execute due to transition to gov2. This was fixed in [referendum 25](https://kusama.subsquare.io/referenda/referendum/25)

So, now we are finally ready to execute our runtime upgrade with the help of the community voting in favor of this referendum.

## runtime upgrade v12

Encointer has a new code upgrade which
* allows participants to unregister from ceremony cycles. This will help us decrease noshows and increase security by doing so
* allows reputables to endorse newbies. This is a massive improvement for growth. Before, only bootstrappers could endorse a one-off amount of newbies. Now, everybody that has recently proven their personhood can endorse a small number (~2-5, TBD) of newbies with every cycle. This is very much in line with the "word of mouth" growth strategy 
* upgrades our dependencies to polkadot-0.9.28

Detailed changes to our [runtime](https://github.com/encointer/encointer-parachain/compare/1.2.0...1.3.2) and to our [pallets](https://github.com/encointer/pallets/compare/1.2.0...1.3.2)


[runtime release v12 in our GH repository](https://github.com/encointer/encointer-parachain/releases/tag/1.3.2)

## The call to be executed on the Encointer parachain with root privilege

[authorizeUpgrade call on Encointer](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Fkusama.api.encointer.org#/extrinsics/decode/0x0102ccdfc804e0482f951ef7ad15fda0d38ead81c42e93a8276e60a45c663b8a3b91
)

## the proposal

[proposal call xcmPallet.send to be executed on Kusama](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Fkusama.api.onfinality.io%2Fpublic-ws#/extrinsics/decode/0x630001000100a50f0204060202286bee880102ccdfc804e0482f951ef7ad15fda0d38ead81c42e93a8276e60a45c663b8a3b91
) yields hash `0x7776194086d1496a812cb61670080157d2f511cbcbaafddd44ff248a753788e7`

## whitelisting by fellowship

Has already passed and call `0x7776194086d1496a812cb61670080157d2f511cbcbaafddd44ff248a753788e7` has been whitelisted

## public referendum

propose to dispatch the whitelisted call

[dispatchProposal](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=wss%3A%2F%2Fkusama.api.onfinality.io%2Fpublic-ws#/extrinsics/decode/0x2c03630001000100a50f0204060202286bee880102ccdfc804e0482f951ef7ad15fda0d38ead81c42e93a8276e60a45c663b8a3b91) encodes to `0x2c03630001000100a50f0204060202286bee880102ccdfc804e0482f951ef7ad15fda0d38ead81c42e93a8276e60a45c663b8a3b91`

items.title: Runtime v9340 Upgrade On Kusama: Fixing OpenGov Parameters and more! (Replacing referendum 254 on Gov1, which failed to execute)
items.content:
The proposal aims to upgrade Kusama's runtime to [v9340](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/releases/tag/v0.9.34): more information about Gov2 can be found in the release notes. This proposal replaces referendum 254 on Gov1: approved by the community but not successfully enacted due to some changes, gov1 got changed to use some of the OpenGov logic: and this failed on dispatch. The original contextual information, below:

**Runtime**

\[S\] âœ… audited [#12310](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/12310) Low - Asset pallet: support repeated destroys to safely destroy large assets

\[S\] [#12848](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/12848) Low - Add `with_weight` extrinsic

\[P\] âœ… trivial [#6372](https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/pull/6372) Low - OpenGov: Kusama tweaks

Proposal hash: `0x0debc0e862468363f53cf1ea4d451ec2fdfc4aeb37a3189354df9597636c55b9`

Note this proposal is submitted with `set_storage` call, not `set_code` call (more info on why `set_code` won't work can be found on [this post](https://polkadot.polkassembly.io/motion/306)).

Preimage:

![](https://i.ibb.co/bbKw1tx/Screenshot-2022-12-07-at-09-53-08.png)

You can review the hash and changes in the release notes and use `SRTool` to verify the proposal hash - make sure to vote at your convenience! This proposal is submitted as an **external motion**: meaning after the Council vote, the community will need to vote on the proposal in the referenda queue.

items.title: Encointer runtime upgrade v12
Emergency Proposal: Recover Kintsugi Parachain
items.content:
Dear fellow Kusama community,

We come to you with a humble but urgent request and need your help. 

### TL;DR:

- The Kintsugi parachain stopped producing blocks at block 1,983,993 [2022-12-01 09:32:18 (+UTC)] due to a Kintsugi-specific issue with the slot duration in Aura
- A fix has been found, tested, and reviewed with the help of Parity
- No user funds are affected as of this writing
- The only way to recover the Kintsugi chain is to update the runtime on the relay-chain via Kusama governance and upgrading all Kintsugi collators


**We are asking the Kusama community to vote on recovering the Kintsugi parachain as soon as possible.**

This is a technical emergency and we are hence requesting the whitelist track for this proposal, to accelerate recovery of Kintsugi.

# Summary

The Kintsugi parachain has stopped producing blocks after a runtime upgrade. The issue is with the slot duration migration and is specific to the Kintsugi chain configuration. No other parachains are affected. See detailed description below. 

The only way to recover the chain is via a Kusama governance proposal.  

No user funds are affected as of this writing. 

**Current status of the network: **All operations are halted. New kBTC cannot be issued and kBTC cannot be redeemed. KINT, kBTC, KSM, LKSM, and any other currency on Kintsugi cannot be moved. There are no KINT rewards for either stakers or vaults. Collateral backing BTC is still locked but collateral thresholds are not enforced at the moment.

Vaults are overall very healthy (https://kintsugi.interlay.io/dashboard/vaults) and no liquidations are expected at this time. There were no pending issues or redeem requests at the time of halting. 

Until Kintsugi is back online and producing blocks:
- All exchanges have been advised to halt withdrawals 
- All XCM-connected parachains have been advised to halt XCM channels 

# Technical Details of the Issue 

## Problem

The issue was caused by a problem with the slot duration. Specifically, there is a panic when a collator tries to produce a block:

```
[Parachain] panicked at 'Timestamp slot must match `CurrentSlot`'
```

Initially, Kintsugi was set at genesis to have a slot duration of 6 seconds but parachains typically have 12 second block times. The other chains built from the interBTC code-base (Interlay, and Interlay and Kintsugi testnets) used 12 seconds. A temporary fix was included in the Kintsugi collators to ensure that block production would succeed even with the 6 second blocktimes. The Kintsugi team did not run a migration as suggested by Parity so the temporary fix remained in place. The missing migration did not cause issues for several runtime upgrades.

However, with the 1.20.0 runtime upgrade we included a recommended change to prevent malicious block producers from potentially building a block. Due to the missing migration, a check in the Aura hook panicked due to an incorrect slot duration calculation which prevented Kintsugi from producing blocks.

Collators are not able to produce new blocks as the relay-chain validation would reject any new blocks with the updated runtime. Unfortunately, this issue was not caught during the release process, code reviews, and testnet upgrades. Also, this issue would not have been caught by the `try_runtime` testing approach as this issue is specific to collator producing blocks and the runtime migrations as such were not an issue. The issue is specific to the Kintsugi configuration and was hence not caught by the testing process on testnet. We are not aware of any other parachains being affected by this. 

A detailed post-mortem will be provided shortly and linked to this proposal. 

## Solution

There are two parts to solve this issue:

1. Updating the Kintsugi runtime on Kusama: Collators are unable to produce blocks. Even by using `codeSubstitutes` Kintsugi cannot recover alone due to the bug described above. Hence, a new wasm needs to be set via Kusama governance on the relay-chain.
2. Updating all collators on Kintsugi to use the patched wasm: Updating the Kintsugi runtime on Kusama needs to be executed together with providing all collators in the Kintsugi network a patched wasm to be used via the `codeSubstitutes` approach.

# Preimage:

- Para: 2092
- newCode: https://github.com/interlay/interbtc/releases/download/1.20.0-hotfix/kintsugi_runtime_parachain.compact.compressed.wasm
and

# References

- https://substrate.stackexchange.com/questions/5828/what-is-codesubstitutes-in-the-chain-spec
- https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/pull/1876
